Example: @akki_dhoni Tum to salo puro movie hi copy karte ho

3. Ad Populum: This fallacy occurs when an argument is made based on appealing to the popularity of a belief or proposition rather than its truthfulness.
Example: If I were a politician hw wld I win against VishGuru I'll nvr raise any questions regarding Corruption Hinduism Patriotism 4VishGuru&Bhakts abv r not all issues I wld corner VishGuru abt ConcentrationCamps GasChambers Genocide VishGuru can't say YES2abv he'll loose27%votes

Example: Ye sala kitni baar nikalenge Mannat ki Name plate 😑😑😑 ye kya Lga rakha h @pooja_dadlani

Instead of focusing on the arguments presented, the post attacks the character of individuals, in this case, Tories, without addressing the actual points being made.

This post uses emotionally charged language to sway opinions rather than relying on logical arguments.

3. This post attempts to influence opinions by appealing to the popularity of the movement rather than presenting coherent arguments.

4. This post implies that investigating individuals will automatically lead to uncovering fraud and corruption without providing any evidence or reasoning.

5. Straw Man: The fallacy of straw man can be found in posts like "I give you the @Conservatives power-play ABC wall of shame - or politics in the pursuit of power for its own sake - AVARICE - BULLYING - CORRUPTION - DECEIT - ENTITLEMENT #GTTO #ToriesOut329 #EnoughIsEnough #GeneralElectionNow https://t.co/InLn0A03xO". Here are some of the intentional fallacies present in the tweets:

1. Ad Hominem: Many of the tweets attack individuals rather than the arguments or ideas they are presenting. For example: "@AndrewScheer No. This shows that Singh HAS principles, because he knows it’s THE CPC selling out Canadians to foreign adversaries, and always has been. So shut the fuck up fatass." This tweet attacks Andrew Scheer personally rather than addressing the substance of his argument.

2. Appeal to Emotions: Some of the tweets appeal to emotions rather than logical reasoning. For example: "@Kassie__Dee Consider this: They are crisis actors and saboteurs paid by CPC and extreme right-wing media to create chaos. It's was proven during the occupation." This tweet attempts to evoke fear and suspicion rather than providing evidence or logical reasoning.

3. Ad Ignorantiam: This fallacy occurs when a statement is claimed to be true because it has not been proven false. For example: "@DavidHamer_1951 Hi Steve and David, I like your list of attempted CPC tear downs, and would add: -The Senate -Chief Justice Beverly MacLaughlin -PETrudeau legacy and all family." This tweet suggests that the claims made against the CPC are true because they have not been disproven.

4. Straw Man: This fallacy involves misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack. For example: "@Arturmaks Then why write a misleading article fully ignoring facts! The CPC is way FAR RW with Fascist ideology so how could anyone even begin to see the Liberals have not changed they have with media and pundits spreading misinformation to deflect those facts." This tweet misrepresents the argument about the Liberals not changing.

5. False Dichotomy: This fallacy presents a situation as if there are only two options, when in reality there are more. For example: "@ryangerritsen So delusional you are! CHONG and the CPC knew about all this for 2 years and CSIS briefed him on any CREDIBLE threats. Only credible threats would have been reported!" This tweet presents the false dichotomy that only credible threats would have been reported, ignoring the possibility of other factors.

These are just a few examples of the intentional fallacies present in the tweets provided.

1. "All politicians are corrupt. Therefore, it's pointless to vote in the upcoming election."
- The fallacy in this post is hasty generalization. This is because the statement makes a broad generalization about all politicians based on the actions of some, without considering the individual actions and intentions of each politician.
Example: "All men are lazy, so they should not be hired for any job."

2. "If you don't support this economic policy, you must not care about helping those in need."
- The fallacy in this post is a false dichotomy. This is because it presents only two options (supporting the economic policy or not caring about those in need) when there are likely more options and reasons for not supporting the policy.
Example: "If you're not with us, then you're against us."

3. "The majority of people support this social program, so it must be the right choice."
- The fallacy in this post is appeal to popularity. This is because it argues that the truth or value of something is based on its popularity, rather than its merits or effectiveness.
Example: "Everyone is wearing these shoes, so they must be the best."

4. "I've always believed in this economic theory, so it must be true."
- The fallacy in this post is appeal to tradition. This is because it argues that something is true or valuable simply because it has been believed or done for a long time, without considering new evidence or perspectives.
Example: "This is how we've always done things, so we should continue doing it that way."

5. "If you don't agree with me on this social issue, then you're just a heartless person."
- The fallacy in this post is ad hominem. This is because it attacks the person's character or motives rather than engaging with their arguments or points of view.
Example: "You're just a selfish person if you don't support this charity."

1. Ad Hominem - This fallacy is present in the tweets that attack individuals rather than addressing their arguments or positions. For example, the tweets that call out Taras Kuzio as a fascist, racist, or unworthy of credibility due to alleged ties with dictators Aliyev and Erdogan are examples of ad hominem fallacies.

2. Appeal to Authority - This fallacy is present in the tweets that use the authority of certain figures or organizations to discredit others. For example, calling out @JacobKamaras from Jerusalem Post as lacking credibility due to his positive statements about Azerbaijan is an appeal to authority fallacy.

3. Appeal to Emotions - This fallacy is present in tweets that use emotional language or appeal to emotions to elicit a specific response without providing logical arguments. For example, tweets that accuse Azerbaijan or Aliyev of ethnic cleansing or genocide are appeals to emotions fallacies.

4. Guilt by Association - This fallacy is present in tweets that attempt to discredit individuals based on their alleged associations with controversial or negative figures. For example, accusing individuals of being paid by dictators like Aliyev or Erdogan to discredit their opinions is a guilt by association fallacy.

5. Straw Man - This fallacy is present in tweets that misrepresent or exaggerate the arguments or positions of others in order to make them easier to attack or refute. For example, accusing Azerbaijan or Aliyev of intending to redesign borders or engage in ethnic cleansing without adequate evidence is a straw man fallacy.

column8:
1. Appeal to Emotions - This fallacy exists in the first post as it appeals to the reader's emotions by using words like "curb plastic pollution" and "Break Free From Plastic" to evoke a sense of urgency and concern. 
Example: "Securing a Global #PlasticsTreaty at the UN can help us curb #plasticpollution and #BreakFreeFromPlastic."

2. Appeal to Popularity - This fallacy exists in the second post as it implies that industry lobbyists will try to weaken countries' resolve, without providing evidence or specific examples, in order to appeal to the popular belief that lobbyists are inherently manipulative and untrustworthy.
Example: "Between now and then, industry lobbyists will try to weaken countries’ resolve to cut #plastic production. Tell @JustinTrudeau we can’t let that happen; we need a strong treaty now!"

3. Straw Man - This fallacy exists in the third post by misrepresenting the position of @s_guilbeault as being opposed to putting limits on production. This misrepresentation creates a false argument that needs refuting.
Example: "The 2nd round of #PlasticsTreaty negotiations have wrapped – and @s_guilbeault has said he’s 'not opposed' to putting limits on production. But he needs to publicly state that a cap & phase down of production MUST be included."

4. Appeal to Emotions - This fallacy again exists in the fourth post as it uses words like "industry lobbyists will try to weaken" and "we need a strong treaty now" to appeal to the reader's emotions and create a sense of urgency.
Example: "UN #PlasticsTreaty negotiations have paused and will resume this fall. Between now and then, industry lobbyists will try to weaken countries’ resolve to cut #plastic production. Tell @JustinTrudeau we can’t let that happen; we need a strong treaty now!"

5. False Cause - This fallacy exists in the fifth post as it implies that cleaning a beach and the issue of plastic pollution are directly correlated, when in reality, cleaning a beach is a temporary solution to a larger problem.
Example: "You can clean a beach – but the plastic always comes back. Securing a Global #PlasticsTreaty at the UN can help us stop #PlasticPollution once and for all."

Overall, these posts contain a variety of logical fallacies that can be spotted by analyzing the language and arguments used in each post.

1. "All politicians are corrupt, so we shouldn't bother voting in the upcoming election."

Fallacy: Sweeping Generalization
Explanation: This tweet makes a sweeping generalization by assuming that all politicians are corrupt without providing evidence or considering any exceptions.

Example: "All dogs are aggressive, so I'll never adopt one as a pet."

2. "If you don't support raising the minimum wage, you don't care about helping working families."

Fallacy: False Dichotomy
Explanation: This tweet presents a false dichotomy by implying that there are only two options - supporting raising the minimum wage or not caring about helping working families - when there may be other factors to consider.

Example: "If you don't like spicy food, you must only eat bland food."

3. "Everyone knows that universal healthcare will bankrupt the country, we can't afford it."

Fallacy: Appeal to Popularity
Explanation: This tweet appeals to popularity by suggesting that everyone knows something to be true, without providing any evidence or considering differing opinions.

Example: "Everyone knows that chocolate is the best flavor of ice cream, so we should only offer that at the party."

4. "If we don't take action on climate change now, the world will end in a few years."

Fallacy: Slippery Slope
Explanation: This tweet uses a slippery slope fallacy by exaggerating the potential consequences of not taking action on climate change to extreme proportions without considering other possible outcomes.

Example: "If we don't leave for the airport right now, we'll miss our flight and our vacation will be ruined."
